Explanations: \text{ The condition does not depend on w, so v can simply be any function with that attribute.}

Question text: \text{Let }L \subseteq Σ^* \text{ be finite. Which of the following languages are semi-decidable?}
Explanations: \text{ The resulting set is finite, so the Language is regular and thus decidable}
\text{ We can check} M_w[x]↓ \text{ for each } x ∈ L.
\text{ The condition is trivially false, so always decidable}

Question text: \text{Is there a regular language }L ∈ NP?
Explanations: \text{ In fact, all regular languages are in NP.}

Question text: \text{For the NP-complete problem SAT, which of the following variants of SAT are NP-complete, assuming } P \neq NP?
AnswerOptions: \text{Each variable } x_{i} \text{ occurs only once in F.}
Explanations: \text{ The formula is always satisfied if all variables are true.}
\text{ One can write} x ∧ y \text{ as } ¬(¬x ∨ ¬y).

\text{ There is always a satisfying assignment with: As long as possible, replace } ¬(x ∧ y) \text{ with } ¬x ∨ ¬y, ¬(x ∨ y) \text{ with } ¬x ∧ ¬y, \text{ and } ¬¬x \text{ with x. Afterward, each variable is still used only once, and negations can only occur directly before variables. If } ¬x \text{  is contained, set x to false, otherwise to true. }

Question text: \text{Which of the following languages are decidable?}
Explanations: L(M_{w}) \text{ is always semi-decidable.}
\text{ Rice's theorem.}
\text{Rice's theorem.}

Question text: \text{Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: \text{Let }L_1 ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be decidable, and }L_2 ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be undecidable. Then } L_1 ∪ L_2 \text{ is undecidable.}
\text{ Let } L_1, L_2 ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be decidable languages. Then }L_1 ∖ L_2 \text{ is decidable.}
\text{ Let }L_1 ⊆ Σ^* \text{ be decidable, and }L_2 ⊆ Σ* \text{ be semi-decidable. Then there exists a } w ∈ Σ^{*} \text{such that }M_{w} \text{ decides the language }L1 ∩ L2.
Explanations: \text{Counterexample:} L1 = Σ^*, L2 = H_0.
\text{ Closure property of decidable Languages}
\text{Counterexample:} L1 = Σ^*, L2 = H_0.

Question text: \text{Which of the following statements are true? }
AnswerOptions: \text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_v := \{w ∈ Σ^*: ww ∈ L(M_{v})\} \text{ is semi-decidable.}
\text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_{v} := \{w ∈ Σ^*: L(M_w) ≠ L(M_v)\} \text{ is semi-decidable.}
\text{ For every } v ∈ Σ^{*}, L_{v} := \{w ∈ Σ^*: w ∉ L(M_v)\} \text{ is semi-decidable. }
Explanations: \text{ Execute }  M_v \text{ on ww.}
\text{ With } L(M_v) = Σ^* \text{ , these are the non-terminating TMs, see Corollary 5.51.}
L_v = \overline{L(M_v)}.

Question text: \text{For the NP-complete problem SAT, which of the following variants of SAT are NP-complete, assuming } P \neq NP?
AnswerOptions: \text{The formula F is in conjunctive normal form, i.e., it has the form } F_1 \wedge \dots \wedge F_m, \text{ where each } F_i \text{ has the form } y_1 \vee \dots \vee y_i \text{ and } y_1, \dots, y_i \text{ are literals.}
\text{The formula F contains each variable } x_i \text{ at most 2022 times.}

\text{The formula F is in disjunctive normal form, i.e., it has the form } F_1 \vee \dots \vee F_m, \text{ where each } F_i \text{ has the form } y_1 \wedge \dots \wedge y_i \text{ and } y_1, \dots, y_i \text{ are literals.}
Explanations: \text{Theorem 6.22.}

\text{For a variable x that occurs more frequently, every second occurrence is replaced by a new variable x', and we consider the new formula } F \wedge (\neg x \vee x') \wedge (\neg x' \vee x)\text{. We repeat this until the condition is met.}
\text{F is satisfiable if one of the } F_i \text{ is. The latter can be easily verified.}

Question text: \text{Let } M := \{L ⊆ Σ^{*}: L ≤_{p} SAT \} \text{ be the set of languages that can be reduced to SAT in polynomial time. Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: If P \neq NP, \text{ then there exists a language } L ∈ M \text{ that cannot be decided by any Turing machine in polynomial time.}
\text{ Every problem in M can be decided by a non-deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time. }
Explanations: \text{ M = NP!, so trivially true}
\text{ M = NP!, so trivially true}
\text{ M = NP!, so trivially true}

Question text: \text{Let } f: \Sigma^{*} \rightarrow \Sigma^{*} \text{ be a computable, partial function. The graph of  f  is the set } \{ (w, f(w)) | w \in \Sigma^{*}, f(w) \neq \perp \}.
Explanations: \text{were it also semi-decidable, we could decide Graph(f),which we can't}
\text{this implies we can check if a word isn't in it,which we can't because of the halting problem }
\text{Given word w: we can simply calculate f(w) and get confirmation.}

Question text: \text{Let } \Sigma := \{a, b\} \text{ and let L} \subseteq \Sigma^{*}. \text{Which of the following statements are true?}
AnswerOptions: If L^{a} \in NP \text{ and } L^{b} \in NP, \text{then} L \ \in NP.
\text{ If } L \in NP, \text{ then } L^{a} \in NP.
Explanations: text{We know that  } L = aL^a \cup bL^b \text{(and epsilon if its part. if e.g }L^b \text{is a undecidable language,it isn`t in NP.)}
\text{We know that  } L = aL^a \cup bL^b \text{(and epsilon if its part). Since NP is closed under Union this holds. }
L^a = aL \text{Since languages in Np are closed under Containation this is in NP!}

Question text: \text{Let } \Sigma \text{ be an alphabet. Let } \mathcal{K} \text{ be the set of all context-free grammars with terminals from } \Sigma.\text{ Given a language }L \subseteq \Sigma^{*}, let \min(L)\text{ be the set of shortest words in L. Which of the following sets are decidable?}
Explanations: \text{This splits down to finding the smallest word of a grammar }G_1 \text{and then checking if its in }G_2 \text{we know that we can check with CYK if w is contained,and the smallest word can be computed by going through its automaton.}
\text{we cannot decide equality for context free languages.}
\text{we can compute if a Language is Empty, but we cant compute}L(G_1)\ L(G_2)

Question text: \text{Reminder: A family of languages is a set of sets. Choose all statements that apply. Note in particular that every decidable set is also semi-decidable.}
AnswerOptions: \text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_{i}\} _{i=1}^{\infty} \text{ over the same alphabet, such that } \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_{i} \text{is not semi-decidable.}
\text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_i\}_{i=1}^{\infty} \text{over the same alphabet, such that }\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_i \text{is undecidable.}
\text{There is a countably infinite family of decidable languages } \{L_i\}_{i=1}^{\infty} \text{over the same alphabet, such that }\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} L_i \text{is decidable.}
Explanations: \text{e.g Let the family be all words of the Halting Problem.(or another not-semidecidable aka undecidable problem)}
\text{e.g Let the family be all words of the Halting Problem.(or another undecidable problem)}
\text{e.g Let the family be all words of L(or another decidable Language)} = a*

Question text: \text{Which of the following problems are decidable?}
AnswerOptions: \text{Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M  with input alphabet }\Sigma\text{ and  }n \in \mathbb{N} . \text{ Problem: Does  M  halt in } n \text{ steps for every arbitrary input } w \in \Sigma^{*} ?
\text{ Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M . Problem: Does  M  visit the start state at least twice with empty input?}
\text{ Given: A deterministic Turing machine  M  and } n \in \mathbb{N} . \text{ Problem: Is there a state such that  M  visits this state at least } n \text{ times with empty input? }
Explanations: \text{ Since only  n  characters can be read in  n  steps, only a finite number of words need to be checked.}
\text{ Reduction from the halting problem.}
\text{ In } |Q|n + 1  \text{ steps,  M  either visits a state at least twice or halts.}

Question text: \text{Let }\Sigma := \{0, 1\}. \text{Which of the following languages are undecidable?}
Explanations: \text{This is just the specific Halting Problem}
\text{We can´t decide if a TM accepts any string,we would need to run it on every possible Input and it might not halt! (Reduktion from the Halting problem)}
\text{To know whether or not a Language is regular,we need to know its members.The amount of members in the Language of a turing maschine is undecidable (in the general) case}

Question text: \text{Let }\Sigma \text{ be an alphabet. Let }f: \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \times \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \rightarrow \mathcal{P}(\Sigma^{*}) \text{ be a function from pairs of languages to languages. Choose all statements that apply.}
AnswerOptions: \text{Assume }f(A, \overline{B}) \text{ is semi-decidable for all semi-decidable languages }A, B. \text{ Then }f(\overline{A}, B) \text{ is also semi-decidable for all semi-decidable languages }A, B.
\text{ Assume }f(A, B) \text{ is decidable for all semi-decidable languages A, B. Let A, B, C be semi-decidable. Then }f(A, f(B, C)) \text{ is decidable.}
\text{ Assume }f(A, \overline{B}) \text{ is semi-decidable for all decidable languages }A, B. \text{ Then }f(\overline{A}, B) \text{ is also semi-decidable for all decidable languages }A, B.
Explanations: \text{}
f(B,C) = X \text{which we know has to be a decidable Set,thus f(A,X) is also decidable}
\text{Let }A = \overline{A}, B =\overline{B} \text{then }f(A, \overline{B}) \equiv f(\overline{A}, B). \text{A,B are still decidable languages because of closure under Komplement.}

Question text: \text{Let L be an arbitrary undecidable language and } a ∈ Σ. \text{Which of the following statements are true?}

Question text: \text{Let } L_1, L_2 \subseteq \Sigma^{*} \text{be decidable languages. Which of the following languages are decidable?}
Explanations: \text{decidable languages are closed under Intersection}
\equiv L_1 \cap \overline{L_2} \text{closed under Komplement and Intersection!}
\text{decidable languages are closed under concatenation}
